texts.definition: Actions by a person in a game world influences how other people perceive and interact with that person.
markups: <style="Definition">Actions by a person in a game world influences how other people perceive and interact with that person.</style>

Perceived actions influence how a non-player character will act toward the acting character. Different types of actions have different consequences: stealing will trigger hostile behavior while doing a favor friendly behavior.

Stealing in the third installment of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> makes player characters lose karma, which in turn changes how other characters reach to them.

Most social interaction performed between Sims in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> change their perception of each other, and in Sims 3 not socializing with a friend for some time may turn them into a distant friend.

A typical prerequisite for <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> is that there are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> defined for the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Either%20You%20are%20with%20Me%20or%20against%20Me">Either You are with Me or against Me</link></style>. These norms are typically either considered universal (except by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Outcasts">Outcasts</link></style>) or common for all those belonging to a <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style>. A special case is the norms constructed by players belonging to the same <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. Regardless of this, the actual consequences can be enforced by global rules (as for example by the karma system in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>), be encoded on an individual level for <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> based on the traits of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or simply result in changed behaviors and attitudes of the other players. The first of these makes it easy to track the consequences, giving <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> for player-controlled <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, but this may be an emergent feature from the latter two. Besides being based on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>, a motivation for <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> can be emotional responses that make psychological sense. An example of this is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Others%20Fortune%20affects%20own%20Mood">Others Fortune affects own Mood</link></style>, which arguably should create happiness when people one likes has good fortune and should create schadenfreude when people one dislikes has bad luck.

However, <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can be achieved by having <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> belong to several different <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>. This since it provides opportunities for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> from different <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> to clash when they meet in a <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style> they have in common. It can also require players to make <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> on whom to support.

Acting against the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> or a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style> is associated with negative behavior (it can be seen as an example of the pattern <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Either%20You%20are%20with%20Me%20or%20against%20Me">Either You are with Me or against Me</link></style>) and should relate to a suitable expression of <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style>; this can be part of the rule set for <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> that are not controlled by humans. Examples of actions that may trigger this includes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, using illegal <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, and engaging in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>. Acting against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> may trigger positive social consequences in the members of another <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style>. For example, breaking a common <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norm</link></style> against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> from one <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> might be required in order to become a member of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> (e.g. a thieves' guild).

<style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> can easily be tied to <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> (for not following <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> (for following them). By doing so, game designs can provide both <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> and ones with clear closures, e.g. passing the requirements of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Gatekeepers">Social Gatekeepers</link></style>. By having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Designed%20Characters">Player-Designed Characters</link></style>, games can allow players to make these choices before gameplay starts. <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style> is interesting as examples of <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> as it can both be good to do and tied to <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> if discovered.

Since <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> are not only about not doing certain things but also that some actions are expected by others, <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> can also have <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style>. Another way of framing this is that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> can require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Maintenance">Diegetic Social Maintenance</link></style> and failure to keep this up leads to consequences.

Living up to or breaking <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> should also be presented diegetically in the reaction of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> in order for <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> to be maintained when this pattern is used.

The presence of <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style> in games can provide easy means to show that <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style>. This both through giving players the possibility to show interest in the <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> by taking on the <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style> but also through the choices they make while performing them. Through having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Multiple%20Endings">Multiple Endings</link></style> based upon the outcome of these <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> the consequences can become even more pronounced.

<style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> often provided <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations for players since there might be <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> associated with breaking <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>, either by doing socially unacceptable actions or failing to do expected actions, but also <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> if this is detected. Depending on how much information players have received about the possible consequences, this may make the choice to perform the actions <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style> or not. If players have the choice of which type of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Faction">Faction</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norm</link></style>) they wish to belong to, <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> provides a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and can support a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> can create a dynamic between the PC and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> and can introduce new conflicts or potential threats to the goals. For <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> which belong to the same <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> as players, this can easily be modeled as cases of <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> in player-controlled <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> this changes the freedom in what actions are possible, and the same applies for <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> when they are nearby. In addition, <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> contributes towards the believability of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> since the pattern can provide <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> when some actions are depicted as being socially unacceptable but still possible to perform. Quite obviously, using <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> to encode that <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> modifies the way the <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> behave during gameplay, and provides means for them to express that they have their <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agendas</link></style>.

As mentioned earlier, if <style="CurrentLink">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</style> are added to actions which are required for <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> the effect is to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Maintenance">Diegetic Social Maintenance</link></style>.
